Hi Andy,

The library provides access to ARC files, providing the following
services right now in my development source:

- Opening and scanning the contents of a GZIP compressed ARC file. It
  does not currently read CDX files because I have no way of creating
  one that I can code against. However, once (if) I add this
  capability then I will not have to scan the archive file to find its
  members because the relevant information can be read from the CDX.

- You can get an iterator to walk over the contents of the ARC file
  member by member (or record by record, to use the ARCReader
  terminology). You can specify a content type to limit the types of
  members you see: text/*, text/html, image/jpeg, etc.

- You can access the information in the URL record and the response
  headers from the HTTP server.

- You can access the member's data in a single call.

- The code currently works on Mac OS X and RedHat Linux 7.3 on x86
  systems. Before I release I am going to build at least on Fedora
  Core 1 (I don't have FC2 installed anywhere), SuSE 64-bit on an
  Opteron, and SPARC/Solaris using the Sun compilers, and probably
  Windows under VC++ 7.0 and Cygwin. Suffice it to say the code is
  portable. It relies on the Zlib library to handle the decompression.

That should be a suitable feature set to get some use out of
it. Moving forward I'm planning to add the following:

- Support for the generation of CDX files, using printf-style format
  strings.

- Support for generating DAT files.

- Support for treating an entire directory of .ARC files as one
  logical ARC, allowing you to transparently iterate over all
  elements.

- Support for arbitrary predicates when selecting members with the
  iterator. For example, you could just iterate over all text/html
  files that had an HTTP response status code of 200, thereby avoiding
  the HTML error pages that sites fondly generate now. Or you could
  iterate over all GIFs (image/gif) and only return those that are
  animated or are larger or smaller than a given dimension.

- Support for regular expression based filters.

- Support for inserting filters between the data contained in raw
  response and the data returned by the iterator. For example, you
  could extract the text from a PDF file.

- Python bindings.

- Support for database integration --- via a class abstraction, with
  initial support for the native MySQL C API.

- Whatever else people suggest.


-- 
Tom Emerson                                          Basis Technology Corp.
Software Architect                                 http://www.basistech.com
